div.p: The Generalized Laplace Transform: Applications to Adaptive Control*
J.M. Davis1, I.A. Gravagne2, B.J. Jackson1, R.J. Marks II2, A.A. Ramos1
This work was supported by NSF Grant EHS#0410685.
Establish a region of convergence for the the forward transform.
Establish a unique inverse transform (and inversion formula).
Explore algebraic properties of the transform: convolution, identity element.
Applications to adaptive control of linear systems (time permitting): controllability and observability for linear systems.

Note that if = 0 this set is a right half plane.

Time varying Hilger circles. The largest, Hmax has center min while the smallest, Hmin has center max. In general, the Hilger circle at time t is denoted by Ht which has center (t). The exterior of each circle is shaded representing the corresponding regions of convergence.

The region of convergence is shaded. On the left, the = 0 case. On the right, the 6= 0 case. In the latter, note our proof of the inversion formula is only valid for Re z > c, i.e. the right half plane bounded by this abscissa of convergence even though the region of convergence is clearly a superset of this right half plane.

< 1 . Finally, if Re (z) > Re (c), then Re (z) > Re (c) for all t T since the Hilger real part is an increasing function in .
Exponential Type I and Type II Functions

The function f : T R is said to be of exponential Type I if there exists constants M, c > 0 such that |f (t)| Mect . Furthermore, f is said to be of exponential Type II if there exists constants M, c > 0 such that |f (t)| Mec (t, 0).
The time scale exponential function, e(t, t0), is Type II.
The time scale polynomials hk (t, 0) are Type I.
Exponential Type I and Type II Functions

The function f : T R is said to be of exponential Type I if there exists constants M, c > 0 such that |f (t)| Mect . Furthermore, f is said to be of exponential Type II if there exists constants M, c > 0 such that |f (t)| Mec (t, 0).
The time scale exponential function, e(t, t0), is Type II.
The time scale polynomials hk (t, 0) are Type I.
Exponential Type I and Type II Functions

The function f : T R is said to be of exponential Type I if there exists constants M, c > 0 such that |f (t)| Mect . Furthermore, f is said to be of exponential Type II if there exists constants M, c > 0 such that |f (t)| Mec (t, 0).
The time scale exponential function, e(t, t0), is Type II.
The time scale polynomials hk (t, 0) are Type I.
Region of Convergence for the Transform

Region of Convergence for the Transform
e z (t, 0)f (t) t converges absolutely for z D if f (t) is of exponential Type II with exponential constant c.
The same estimates used in the proof of the preceding theorem can be used to show that if f (t) is of exponential Type II with constant c and Re (z) > Re (c), then limt e z (t, 0)f (t) = 0.
Let F denote the generalized Laplace transform for f : T R. F (z) is analytic in Re (z) > Re (c).
F (z) is bounded in Re (z) > Re (c).
Let f : T R have generalized Laplace transform F (z). Then f (0) = limz zF (z),
limt f (t) = limz0 zF (z) when the limits exist.

Does there exist a contour in the complex plane around which it is possible to integrate to obtain the same results through a more operational approach?

For T = R or T = Zyes! If T is completely discrete, then if we choose any circle in the region of convergence which encloses all of the singularities of F (z), the inversion formula holds. In general? Sorry, just dont know... (Want a problem to work on?)

We can use these techniques to generate generalized (and unified) versions for any canonical transforms (e.g. Fourier, Mellin, Hankel, etc.).

For any transformable function f (t) on T, there is a shadow function f (t) defined on R. That is, to determine the appropriate time scale analogue of the function f (t) in terms of the transform, we use the diagram to map its Laplace transform on R to its Laplace transform on T.
We can use these techniques to generate generalized (and unified) versions for any canonical transforms (e.g. Fourier, Mellin, Hankel, etc.).

The last equality is justified since the function
is the unique solution to the initial value problem
In a similar manner, we can use an induction argument coupled with the Inversion Theorem to show that the inverse of F (z) = 1
zk+1 , for k a positive integer, is hk (t, 0).

In fact, it easy to show that the inversion formula gives the claimed inverses for any of the elementary functions that Bohner and Peterson have in their table. These elementary functions become the proper time scale analogues or shadows of their continuous counterparts.
In a similar manner, we can use an induction argument coupled with the Inversion Theorem to show that the inverse of F (z) = 1
zk+1 , for k a positive integer, is hk (t, 0).

Consider the function F (z) = e z ((a), 0). The Inversion Theorem cannot be applied. However, if a is right scattered, one can show that the Hilger Delta function which has representation
has F (z) as a transform, while if a is right dense, the Dirac delta functional has F (z) as a transform.
Consider the function F (z) = e z ((a), 0). The Inversion Theorem cannot be applied. However, if a is right scattered, one can show that the Hilger Delta function which has representation
has F (z) as a transform, while if a is right dense, the Dirac delta functional has F (z) as a transform.

If two functions f and g have the same transform, then are f and g necessarily the same function? As on R, the answer to this question is affirmative if we define our equality in an almost everywhere (a.e.) sense.

Upshot (after some measure theoretic hoops to jump thru): To show that a property holds almost everywhere on a time scale, it is necessary to show that the property holds for every right scattered point in the time scale, and that the set of right dense points for which the property fails has Lebesgue measure zero.
If the functions f : T R and g : T R have the same Laplace transform, then f = g a.e.

The delay of the function x : T R by ( ) T, denoted by x(t, ( )), is given by
Here, u(t) : T R is the time scale unit step function activated at time t = T.
Notice that u( )(t)x(t, ( )) has transform X (z)e z (, 0).

This allows us to use the term delay to describe x(t, ( )), since on T = R, the transformed function X (z)ez corresponds to the function u (t)x(t ). With the delay operator defined, we define the convolution of two arbitrary transformable time scale functions.
The convolution of the functions f : T R and g : T R, denoted f ? g , is given by
The transform of a convolution product is the product of the transforms.
Proof. Assuming absolute integrability of all functions involved, then by the delay property and inversion we obtain
Example. Suppose g (t, ( )) = 1. In this instance, we see that for any transformable function f (t), the transform of h(t) =
another result obtained by direct calculation in Bohner and Peterson.

The convolution product is both commutative and associative. Indeed, the products f ? g and g ? f have the same transform as do the products f ? (g ? h) and (f ? g ) ? h, and since the inverse is unique, the functions defined by these products must agree almost everywhere.

At first glance, one may think that the identity is vested in the Hilger Delta. Unfortunately, this is not the case. It can be easily shown that any identity for the convolution will of necessity have transform 1 by the convolution theorem. But the the Hilger Delta does not have transform 1 since its transform is just the exponential.

independently of the time scale involved.
Also, if g (t) = e z (t, 0), then a, g = e z (a, 0), so that for a = 0, the Dirac delta functional 0(t) has Laplace transform of 1, thereby giving us an identity element for the convolution.

However, our definition of the delay operator will only hold for functions. It will be necessary to extend this definition for the delta functional. To maintain consistency with the delta functions action on g (t) = e z (t, 0), it follows that for any t T, the shift of a( ) is given by a(t, ( )) = t (( )).
Just as before, the algebraic properties hold in this setting, e.g.

When we perform the convolution g , , we must give meaning to this symbol and do so by defining (t) to be the Kronecker delta when t is right scattered and the Dirac delta if t is right dense. While this ad hoc approach does not address convolution with an arbitrary (shifted) distribution on the right, this will suffice (at least for now) since our eye is on solving generalizations of canonical partial dynamic equations which will involve the Dirac delta distribution.
Uniqueness of the inverse of the Dirac delta?
Yes, just need a new commutative diagram betwixt the dual spaces.
Uniqueness of the inverse of the Dirac delta?
Yes, just need a new commutative diagram betwixt the dual spaces.
is called controllable on [t0, tf ] if given any initial state x0 there exists a rd-continuous input signal u(t) such that the corresponding solution of the system satisfies x(tf ) = xf .

is called observable on [t0, tf ] if any initial state x(t0) = x0 is uniquely determined by the corresponding response y (t) for t [t0, tf ).
The regressive linear system given above is observable on [t0, tf ] if and only if the n n observability Gramian matrix
